content: The Act may be cited as the "Panama-Pacific International Exposition and Panama Canal Commemorative Coins Act". The 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco commemorated the completion of the Panama Canal and the 400th anniversary of the discovery of the Pacific Ocean. It played a significant role in the economic recovery of San Francisco after the 1906 earthquake. President William Howard Taft chose San Francisco as the location, and construction began in 1911. The Exposition featured hundreds of temporary buildings on the grounds. The 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco featured buildings representing every state in the Union and 22 foreign governments. The fair occupied 76 city blocks, with the Palace of Fine Arts being the only building to survive. The United States Mint issued five different coins in connection with the Exposition, including the first commemorative coins to bear the motto "In God We Trust". The 1915 Panama-Pacific International Exposition in San Francisco featured various buildings representing states and foreign governments. The United States Mint issued commemorative coins, including a silver Panama-Pacific half dollar and four gold coins, with the largest being a unique $50 octagonal coin. The Panama Canal, built between 1890 and 1914, was a significant engineering feat led by President Theodore Roosevelt after the failed French attempts. The Panama Canal, built between 1890 and 1914 for $40 million, connected the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, saving sailors an 8,000-mile journey. The Canal opened on August 15, 1914, marking a monumental achievement. The United States should commemorate the centennial in San Francisco and support educational programs through the sale of commemorative coins. The curr_chunk discusses the programs of the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society and the preservation of Theodore Roosevelt's home in Oyster Bay, New York. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 octagonal and round gold coins, each limited to 50,000 coins, and $1 silver coins limited to 500,000 coins. The coins have specific weights, shapes, and compositions as outlined in the Act. The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Half dollar coins shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The design of coins is specified in the Act, with details on weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall closely resemble historical gold coins and medals, with specific requirements for $5 octagonal and round gold coins. The coins minted under this Act shall have an obverse depicting the head of the goddess Minerva with a Corinthian-style helmet, and a reverse depicting an owl perched on a pine bough with pine cones and needles, surrounded by inscriptions for the Panama-Pacific Exposition and San Francisco. The $1 silver coins minted under this Act shall have an obverse and reverse design featuring stylized dolphins in the eight angles of the vertices and a likeness of the Roosevelt Medal awarded for work on the Panama Canal. The $1 silver coins minted under an Executive order by President Theodore Roosevelt in 1907, designed by F.D. Millet and struck by the United States Mint in Philadelphia. The obverse depicts President Theodore Roosevelt, while the reverse shows the Culebra Cut excavation through the Cordillera Mountains in the Canal Zone. The curr_chunk describes the design specifications for half dollar clad coins minted under an Act, resembling the 1915 Panama Pacific Exposition half dollar coin. The design includes the motto "THE LAND DIVIDED, THE WORLD UNITED" and the option to omit the legend "PRESENTED BY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES" after consultation with relevant committees. The Panama Pacific Exposition half dollar coin features an obverse with Columbia scattering flowers towards a sunset on the Golden Gate and a reverse with an eagle resting on the union shield. The design is credited to Charles Barber and George T. Morgan, respectively. Each coin minted under this Act will have specific designations and inscriptions. The Act specifies the design and inscriptions for the coins, including the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The Secretary will select the design in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2015. SEC. 6 of the Act outlines the sale of coins by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales are offered at a discount, and prepaid orders are accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act include surcharges of $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received are paid to the San Francisco Museum and Historical Society for exhibitions and adaptive reuse of the Old Mint. Exhibitions at the Palace of Fine Arts on the grounds of the former Panama-Pacific International Exposition. One-fourth of surcharges go to the National Park Foundation for programs at President Theodore Roosevelt's home in Oyster Bay, New York. The Comptroller General can audit organizations receiving surcharge funds. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual limit of 2 commemorative coin programs.
